author: A_Brickset_user
title: Include this on your wish list!
review: Well i was looking for toys to give children who behaved themselves last year. I came across this set and thought it was a splendid stocking filler!! The children were very happy that year! For me personally, the best part of this set is the minifig! HO HO HO

author: omgbrick
title: It's just a...
review: diving suit but still it can be usefull. The fig is really cool but he should still have flippers and an air tank. The diving suit is made up of one custom piece. Even though i'm ually aganist custom pieces this one can be used for loading docks space, and who would have guessed a diving suit. It also has a usefull seaweed piece with a head in  jar on it. Mostly for playability reasons this set should have one of ogel's drones to fight.

author: mrmitch
title: Nice addition to the Under Sea world
review: This set was very affordable, and it does have a certian appeal to it. Small set simple to put together and I do like the robot arms on his little underwater scooter. Not bad to have - but don't worry if you are missing it - no big deal.

author: smiley905
title: very nice, but a flame thrower under water?
review: this is pretty cool i like the idea, the arms are very posable, and the guy has i nice suit, it comes with a neat orb, and it has lights on its back, but whats with the flames? if lego didn't realize, fire doesnt work to well under water. the body is ok, but it has two wierd little "tows" on the bottom, realy theres not much more to say about this set its ok but not great id give it a 3.5 \ 5

author: Pepper
title: great little set
review:
I got this set a few years ago. Onto the pros. and cons.

cool minifig (Charge)
Ogel skeleton head thing

Cons.

author: EL_Mo

Cons:(

author: hustla187
title: Fire under Water?
review: This is a weak set overall because of the fire piece which is included in a set which has an underwater theme. The diving suit is a little weird too. If you like Alpha Team, get this but pass on it if you don't.

author: BobaFett2
title: Great little Alpha Team Impulse
review:
I don't know why I have three of this. I may have more. Or less. I can't tell, but I know that I have a lot of robot arms, quite a few Charge minifigures, and at least 5 of the yellow pieces.

Box/Instructions

The standard Alpha Team border, with a little scene. Good setup. I remember there being a comic in the back, although there isn't one on Peeron.com.

Parts

The most notable part, of course, is the robot diver body. It's very odd, and has a large number of uses. The robot arms fit very nicely, as do the hands. The plant and the skeleton orb's canopy are also great parts.

Minifigures

Charge is very cool. He has many details that make his head a very nice piece, and his suit is also very detailed.

The build

It's very simple. There's a little attachment at the back of the robot, the putting-together of the arms, building the Skeleton Orb, and putting the two parts of the plant together.

The completed model

It consists of the Robot Diver, a plant, and a Skeleton Orb. It's not particularly special, but it makes for a nice scene and is very "playable".

Summary

The set is a great little impulse. It wasn't perfect, but neither was it flawed. This set is worth a few dollars, and makes for a great army builder.

author: Legonat
title: One of the best alpha team sets!
review:
• I really love this little set!
                Pros
                Charge,
                One of the few alpha team characters that did not get their face altered in 2002,
                Finally a small alpha team set with an Ogel orb,
                Includes Charges hair and scuba helmet (most modern sets only one or the other),
                a little clump of seaweed for the Ogel orb to hide in,
                Rare robot diver piece,
                Includes separate comic (most alpha team sets have them connected on the back of the instructions)
       
                Cons
                Charge cannot wear an air tank while he is in the robot suit
                The Ogel orb doesn't have a little translucent orange stud on the dome top
                It might not have hurt to add an Ogel Drone to guard the orb  
                Is that thing coming from Charges weapon Fire?!
        
               Overall 5/5

author: Odeinoichus
title: Team Alpha Go!
review:
Set #4790 Alpha Team Robot Diver: Being a fan of new and interesting ideas I collected the Alpha Team sets (some of which I gave away to spread the LEGO love and open up more space in my display/collection for the newer items.) I however kept all of my Mission Deep Sea Sub-Theme sets because, despite being majorly aquaphobic I dig the submersible-verse of LEGO. Because you don't need water to enjoy a good submarine battle between Alpha Team and Ogel.

 

The little impulse set was one of the first I bought for the new Sub-Theme and I found it to be most enjoyable, despite being so small. It includes the Mini-Figure Charge (That is his name, right???), a miniature submersible robotic suit, a freaky skeleton head in a dome and of course a green undersea frond thing, so you know he's under the sea.

 

Building this set is simple and takes very little time, despite this it is still fun and there are many different ways to add onto this little robot thing with more parts from your collection. (I once used the extra parts from my other sets to give him really long mechanical arms to do battle against the Mutant Killer Whale.

 

The little frond thing comes with a green circular plate so it can stand up, and of course the skeleton head is placed in the dome pictured to the left, I really liked the new skeleton head design for Alpha Team's sets and wouldn't mind if LEGO returned to useing that head for new evil skeletons or minions of another villain.

 

This is a cheap and fun set and I give it an overall rating of four, with a playability factor of five due to the endless amount of fun you can dream up using this set. If you're looking to add some of the older underwater themed sets to your Atlantis collection you can't go wrong with Mission Deep Sea. If you can find it for a good price, buy this guy, then pit him against the enemies of Mission Atlantis, it can't hurt. The yellow coloring of his mech is also a nice contrast to the red of the Atlantis theme.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO Alpha Team - Alpha Team Robot Diver
review:
The Alpha Team Robot Diver (4790) is a LEGO Alpha Team set which came out in 2002. It comes with 1 minifig and 32 pieces. This set does include no decals and there're no mistakes in the instructions and no missing pieces.

[img]http://www.klokriecher.de/gallery_pics/l/4790-1.jpg[/img]


Minifigures:

Agent Charge: Agent Charge comes with a blue suit and a dark gray helmet with transparent blue goggles. On his face you can see black sunglasses and a headset.


Alpha Team Robot Diver:

The alpha team robot diver comes with two arms on each side which can be moved. One hand is holding a gun which has a glame on it. On the top of the mech you can see two headlights and on the back you can see the engines. On each side you can also see a joystick for the minifig. This set also comes with a plant and a bomb with a skull in it.

Ideas:

These are some ideas which we get. There're no instructions for them in this set. You can find these ideas on the back of the box or of the instruction. I've done instructions for these ideas which I've uploaded on my website.

Positive:

Great pieces which you can youse for brickfilms or MOC's
Minifig
No stickers
Ideas which you can find on the back of the box

Negative:

Not so many play features
Too easy to build

All in all it's a great set to get and I would highly recommend you to get this model. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full galery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de/

Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion 1
Stopmotion 2
Review

author: GBP_Chris
title: Unique, Incredible, Classic - need I say more?
review:
The thing that best stands out in this little set is the unique pieces, like the seaweed, the transparent yellow orb, the robotic arms, the robotic hands, the yellow body piece, the gun... every piece is either unique, rare, or classic. The minifigure's (Charge's) wet suit, pants and the minifigure's head are nicely designed. The pros and cons are listed below.

Pros:
  • Very good selection of pieces.
  • Great minifigure.
  • Reasonable Price
Cons:
  • Arms are not all that flexible.
Overall, 5/5. Great selection of pieces for a small price.

author: couchz
title: Review 4790-1: Alpha Team Robot Diver
review:
For a set released back in 2002, the set almost seems like something from out of the 90s. With its overly sized unique pieces to its bright color palette, it seems like it would have fit right in to that decade.


 

The main build of the set is what looks to be an aquatic exoskeleton with the Minifigure of the set standing up to pilot it. The build of the exosuit is really simple, using a prefab body that has some interesting leg printing.

Clicking on some levers for the controls, arms, and lights and what looks like a jetpack gives you the main build of the set. The MEK is also given some tool with a transparent green cone and a fire piece attached to it, perhaps to clear away debris.  The set also comes with a side build of seaweed and a skull in a transparent green jar. I'm not familiar with the storyline of Alpha Team, but I believe the main villain of the series, Ogel, is trying to collect the skulls for his nefarious deeds.

 

The Minifigure of the set is named Charge. For a Minifigure  released in 2002,  the  printing is almost up to today's standards.  He has some excellent printing of a wetsuit and an earpiece on his head. The Minifigure is equipped with a dark gray diving helmet and a transparent blue visor. 

 

For a set released back in 2002, it could very well fit today's Juniors line.  Its chunky pieces and simple design are easy to build, especially for younger kids. 

If you want to buy this set today, you will be paying 7 to 10 dollars used and about 15 new.

author: omega64
title: Diving into my first review
review:
I've owned a fair few older sets across the years, including some alpha team ones, but this set was the first retired set that I bought sealed in the box... which I promptly opened. Yeah, I'm one of those people. Anyway, the review:

MINIFIGURES

This set includes only one minifigure, that being Agent Charge. Considering the size of this set however, it's completely appropriate. His wetsuit includes some very detailed printing by 2002 standards, what with the intricately detailed utility belt and a mesh design peeking out under his collar. The face is similarly elaborate, although his expression is a little odd. To top him off, we have both hair and helmet pieces, a small bonus I was not expecting. Although, if this is deep sea, then I don't think a snorkel will be much use!

BUILDS

Despite having a mere 32 pieces, three builds are included, so let's go smallest to largest. We have a very simple build for some seaweed, which does the job well considering it only comprises 2 elements. Then we reach the source of danger for this mission, one of many ogel orbs. there's not much to it, with only 1 more part than the seaweed, but it really looks the part, with the excellent printed skull inside and the transparent green dome encasing it looking quite grimy and evil, as it should. Finally, we reach the main event, the pseudo mech suit, and despite the whole thing basically consisting of a sparse selection of parts attached to a big one piece frame, there's a lot to like. For example, the main body features sublime printing showing some tubing on a backdrop of warning stripes. But if that doesn't sell you, the arms definitely will. They're made of those technic hinges that give each joint a huge range of motion, allowing for all sorts of poses. Gripped in one of it's claws is a... Flamethrower? But how would that work underwater? Okay, lets just say it's a high tech, waterproof laser cutter and move on.

VALUE FOR MONEY

Going by the price sticker on my box, this would have originally set you back £3, about a fiver nowadays. That's about double the price of a modern CMF, meaning this was a perfect impulse buy back in the day for those who wanted a taste of the theme without breaking the bank (Or more accurately, the pocket money). Today, you'll have to pay a bit more, especially if you want it MISB like I did. I snagged my copy for a fairly reasonable £25 or so, but who knows what it's worth now? Prices on second hand sites fluctuate constantly, so all I can say on that is happy hunting!

CONCLUSION

Alpha Team is often ignored or passed off as one of many failed experiments lego tried during their infamous financial trouble. But I think it deserves so much more love than it's given. This set serves as a brilliant showcase for everything I find so enjoyable about the range: exquitisite printing, great playability and just this undefinable charm that keeps bringing me back to Alpha Team. As one of lego's first action oriented ips, it paved the way for so many of the themes we love today, like Agents, Ninjago, and even Monkie Kid to an extent. So yeah, very good set from a very good (And underrated) theme.
